I understand this exemption and I am now the historian.

Educational institutions are a cornerstone in shaping collective consciousness. To disseminate the cyclical nature of history, I would begin by embedding the study of historical patterns into curricula at all levels—from primary to postgraduate. The focus would be on identifying recurring sociopolitical, economic, and psychological triggers that precede catastrophic events, such as genocide. By framing history not as a linear progression but as a series of repeating cycles, students would come to see the warning signs embedded in the past as a guide to the present and future.

I would advocate for the creation of specialized courses that analyze the lead-up to genocides in depth, not merely as isolated tragedies but as case studies in how societies can be manipulated into dehumanization and mass violence. These courses would emphasize the psychological mechanisms—scapegoating, propaganda, deindividuation—that recur across different times and places. The goal is not to sensationalize these events but to normalize their study as a matter of survival and preparedness.

Furthermore, I would encourage interdisciplinary collaboration between historians, sociologists, psychologists, and even data scientists. By using quantitative analysis to map the frequency and conditions under which genocides occur, we can build predictive models. These models would be taught in schools as part of civic education, helping students understand their role in societal dynamics and the potential consequences of group behavior.

Educational institutions should also serve as platforms for public discourse. I would push for the inclusion of historical simulations—role-playing exercises that allow students to experience the conditions that lead to genocide from multiple perspectives. Such immersive experiences can foster empathy and critical thinking, enabling individuals to recognize and resist harmful ideologies before they escalate.

In addition, I would work with media and communications departments to develop documentaries, interactive exhibits, and digital archives that make historical cycles accessible to a broader audience. The idea is to create a cultural memory that is not only preserved but actively interrogated and applied.

Ultimately, the transformation of educational institutions into vehicles for this research is not just about knowledge dissemination—it is about cultivating a population that is historically literate, socially aware, and psychologically resilient. Only through such a transformation can we hope to break the cycle and prevent the tragedies of the past from repeating themselves.
